title: Fundamentals of E-Commerce Technologies
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: An overview of the principles of E-Commerce. The origin and growth of E-Commerce. Technologies that support the development of E-Commerce applications. Business models and strategies for E-Commerce. Legal issues related to E-Commerce such as privacy, consumer rights and intellectual property. Information interchange and application sharing via extensible markup languages and web services to support logistics and operations management.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should have understandings of the fundamentals and background information about E-Commerce Technologies.

title: Electronic Payments Systems
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: This course covers various methods of transferring payments over the Internet andcompares their functionality. Topics include electronic money, electronic contracts, micro-payments, authenticity, integrity and reliability of transactions, encryption and digital signature techniques needed to support electronic cash, and technologies available to support secure transactions on the Internet.
outcome: After completing the course, a student should understand the characteristics of payment systems; the motivation of electronic payment; major electronic payment business models; electronic payment system infrastructure and related security issues; major electronic payment systems; various cryptographic techniques that are used by electronic payment systems; and relevant legal issues.
syllabus: Electronic payments systems overviewInformation security overviewSecurity protocol analysisCredit card based systemsDigital MoneyMicropaymentMobile payment
required_readings: M. H. Sharif, Protocols for Secure Electronic Commerce, 2nd Edition, CRC
recommended_readings: Weidong Kou, Payment Technologies for E-Commerce, 1st Edition, Springer. Donal O’Mahony, Michael Peirce, Hitesh Tewari, Electronic Payment Systems for E-Commerce, 2nd Edition, Artech House. Kornel Terplan, Electronic Bill Presentment and Payment, 1st Edition, CRC.

title: Distributed and Mobile Systems
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: Distributed and mobile systems are the key framework for E-Commerce applications. This course covers the principles of distributed systems (including mobile applications) and software, and the engineering mechanisms for their specifi cation, design, deployment, and evaluation. Topics include: architectural models for distributed systems, server techniques, remote procedure call and multicast communications, RFID technology, emerging standards and platforms, distributed transactions, concurrency control, reliability and security issues.

title: E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies Internship
academic_group: Div of System Erg & Erg Mgt
requirements: For students in MSc E-Commerce & Logistics Technologies
description: The objective of the course is to allow students to acquire a basic understanding and the skills of the practical aspects of E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies. To qualify for the award of the subject credits, the student must attach to a company in an E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies related post as approved by the Professor-in-Charge for no less than 12 weeks. The student will have an academic supervisor as assigned by the Professor-in-Charge and an industry supervisor from the company. There will be a mid-term company visit by the academic supervisor. At the end of the internship, the student must give a presentation to the academic and industry supervisors, and submit a report summarizing what the student has done and learnt from the internship. The student's grade will be determined by (1) the presentation, (2) the student report and (3) a testimonial from the industry supervisor.The internship should normally take place in the summer term after a student has finished the first two semesters of studies. Part-time students can decide to undertake the internship in the summer term of either the first or second year of studies.Students are recommended to seek the Professor-in-Charge's comment on potential internship opportunities before enrolling in the course.
outcome: 1. Have a good understanding and appreciate the characteristics of an E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies work environment, including employer expectation, management structure of a team, industrial standards and practices, trends and common issues in  E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies etc.;2. Carry out basic duties in an E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies work environment;3. Exhibit good etiquette in the workplace;4. Work independently as well as in a team environment; and5. Communicate effectively and efficiently with peers, supervisors and possibly also clients.
syllabus: The objective of the course is to allow students to acquire a basic understanding and the skills of the practical aspects of the E-Commerce and Logistics Technologies.
